Title: I Tried Aldi's Diet Coke Copycat And It's Not Even Close To Everyone's Favorite Fridge Cig
URL: https://www.tastingtable.com/2013384/aldi-summit-diet-cola-diet-coke-copycat-review/
Time Published: 2025-11-02T18:20:00Z
Full Content:
As of 2025, Diet Coke reigns as the number one diet soda in the U.S., which doesn't surprise me at all. I will check and see if restaurants have Coke or Pepsi before I go. I'm that picky. And I'm not the only fan! Diet Coke ranks fifth among all top-selling sodas in general, coming in after regular Coca-Cola, Dr Pepper, Sprite, and Pepsi, in that order. And there are a lot of sodas out there! But recently, we heard a little rumor that there was a Diet Coke dupe that tasted even better and was cheaper, which had us more than intrigued. Personally, as a diehard Diet Coke fan, I have to say I was incredibly suspicious and needed to do my own investigating. (Those are some pretty big claims to be making.) The copycat ‚Äî Aldi's Summit brand diet cola ‚Äî is one of many dupes by this grocery store. Luckily, there is an Aldi very close to me, so I ran right out to grab a 12-pack. Already having Diet Coke on hand, because I use it in everything from mocktails and cocktails to baking sweet treats, it would be easy to do a head-to-head taste test. Giving each a 24-hour window to chill in my refrigerator, I sat down to taste them. I was ready for anything. I took a deep breath and opened my mind to the possibilities. Would it taste the same? Would it actually be better? Well, here's what I found. When working on this piece, Summit Diet Cola was available at my Aldi for $4.69 for a 12-pack of 12-ounce cans. There are over 2,500 Aldi locations scattered through 39 states in the U.S. So, the availability is somewhat accessible, although not as widely distributed as Diet Coke. As far as Diet Coke goes, at my local Kroger, there is always a BOGO sale going on, so I always stock up. The week I purchased these sodas, it was a buy two, get three free weekend sale. With a 12-pack of 12-ounce cans costing $10.99, that worked out to $4.39 per pack, which was an even better deal than Aldi. While Kroger only operates in 16 states and territories, I feel like there are other stores that probably offer similar discounts. When I checked out Walmart prices at the time of this writing, it had 24-packs of Diet Coke cans for $13.78, making a 12-pack $6.89. And Walmart does operate in all 50 states. Additionally, Costco (operating in 49 states and territories) had 35-packs of cans for $19.85, which would leave you paying around $6.60 per 12-pack. So, there are deals to be had if cost is an issue. I cracked open the chilled can of Summit Diet Cola and went in for my first taste. It had an immediate sweet cloud that covered my palate and filled my mouth. There was a nice carbonation about it that tingled my tongue and gave the soda an overall round, full profile. Oddly, there was an overly obvious citrus taste to it that reminded me of the lemon and lime flavor of Sprite, but with a touch of vanilla. It wasn't bad, just odd. But it couldn't garner too much attention, as the sweet flavor demanded center stage throughout. The sweetness tasted artificial and exceedingly apparent, like a small child vying for the spotlight. It carried the flavor in and stayed long after any citrus, spice, or carbonation was gone. And while it didn't go over the top or become offensive, it was still somehow larger than it needed to be. In the end, all the tastes stopped very abruptly, leaving the palate seemingly coated with a nothingness that wasn't entirely clean. This diet cola wasn't bad, but it was very obviously an off-brand, a generic interpretation of something familiar. I could taste what it was trying to achieve, but it tried too hard and missed the mark with its overzealous flavoring. Taking a sip of Diet Coke offered a layer of flavors and carbonation to cascade across my taste buds, dancing with tiny, prickling bubbles. There seemed to be a blanket of caramel that was soft, lush, and slightly sweet. Underneath the caramel was a hint of citrus that seemed to complement the spicy aesthetic without drawing too much attention to itself. The sweetness of it all seemed to be but a welcome guest of equal measure on the journey of flavors. Nothing tasted to stand out on its own; rather, every flavor worked together in harmony. The flavors of Diet Coke appeared to be deliberately refined, balanced on rich fizz that teased the taste buds into new heights of enjoyment. And when it left my mouth, the flavors and slight burn of carbonation lingered only for a moment before taking their final leave. Overall, refreshing and soft but strong, drinking Diet Coke was incredibly satisfying. I tasted both diet sodas over ice, one at a time. Then, I did the same straight from the can. To ensure I was comparing them as accurately as possible, I also went back and forth, taking sips side by side. The Summit Diet Cola had flavors that were audacious compared to Diet Coke. They went too far, became too artificial, and were too sweet. Instead of working together, the Summit Diet Cola came across as a battle for attention from one flavor to the next, while Diet Coke's flavor, carbonation, and sweetness all worked in tandem to complement and enhance each other's qualities. It would be one thing if rumors had said that this dupe was somewhat comparable. That I could see. Both sodas have a citrus component, an artificial sweetness, and a caramel aesthetic. However, Diet Coke remained subdued in all its flavors and maintained a refreshing quality that was enjoyable rather than complicated. Summit, on the other hand, was like a little kid dressing up in their parents' clothes, trying to be something it wasn't, and ending up as an obvious farce. Diet soda alternatives keep coming after Diet Coke. But I just don't believe that any of them will ever beat the OG. And why do we need them to? With the ability to get discounts or bulk amounts of Diet Coke, the savings are negligible. You just need to look around and see where you can find the best deal. To get the best taste, I feel it's more than worth it.
--------------------------------------------------

Title: Meta has an AI product problem¬† | TechCrunch
URL: https://techcrunch.com/2025/11/02/meta-has-an-ai-product-problem/
Time Published: 2025-11-02T16:13:58Z
Full Content:
Latest AI Amazon Apps Biotech & Health Climate Cloud Computing Commerce Crypto Enterprise EVs Fintech Fundraising Gadgets Gaming Google Government & Policy Hardware Instagram Layoffs Media & Entertainment Meta Microsoft Privacy Robotics Security Social Space Startups TikTok Transportation Venture Staff Events Startup Battlefield StrictlyVC Newsletters Podcasts Videos Partner Content TechCrunch Brand Studio Crunchboard Contact Us In the midst of an unprecedented AI buildout, Meta is spending more than most. The company is building two massive data centers, and reporting indicates there will be as much as $600 billion in spending on U.S. infrastructure over the next three years. Those figures might not raise eyebrows in Silicon Valley, but they‚Äôre starting to make Wall Street nervous. The issue came to a head this week as Meta reported quarterly earnings, which showed the company‚Äôs operating expenses jumping $7 billion year-over-year and nearly $20 billion in capital expense. It was the result of intense spending on AI talent and infrastructure, which has yet to bring in meaningful revenue for the company. When analysts pressed for more specifics, Mark Zuckerberg made it clear the spending was just getting started. ‚ÄúThe right thing to do is to try to accelerate this to make sure that we have the compute that we need, both for the AI research and new things that we‚Äôre doing, and to try to get to a different state on our compute stance on the core business,‚Äù Zuckerberg told analysts on the call. ‚ÄúOur view is that when we get the new models that we‚Äôre building in MSL in there and get like truly frontier models with novel capabilities that you don‚Äôt have in other places, then I think that this is just a massive latent opportunity.‚Äù If his goal was to reassure investors, it didn‚Äôt work. By the end of the call, Meta‚Äôs share price had plummeted in value. Two days later, the rout has only deepened. The Meta‚Äôs stock dropped 12% by the closing bell on Friday, representing more than $200 billion in lost market cap. It‚Äôs dangerous to read too much into stock prices, and in strict financial terms, Meta‚Äôs quarterly earnings weren‚Äôt that bad. ($20 billion in quarterly profit is nothing to complain about.) But this was the first quarter in which Meta‚Äôs aggressive AI spending on both talent and infrastructure had a visible impact on the company‚Äôs bottom line. Even more alarming was that, aside from a lot of enormous data centers and well-compensated AI researchers, it wasn‚Äôt clear what the money actually bought. Analysts pressed Zuckerberg on why he was spending so much on AI, and when they could expect to see revenue from the growing spending. But the call came at an odd spot in Meta‚Äôs planning, with no clear budget for projected spending and no available product that could anchor a revenue forecast. As a result, Zuckerberg was left with only general claims about the promise of AI. ‚ÄúThere are going to be all kinds of new products around different content formats, and we‚Äôre starting to see that,‚Äù he asid during the call. ‚ÄúAnd then there are the business versions of all these too, like business A ‚Ä¶ the other part is how more intelligent models are just going to improve the core business and improve the recommendations that we make across the Family of Apps and improve the recommendations in advertising.‚Äù Meta isn‚Äôt the only company spending billions of dollars on AI infrastructure, so it‚Äôs worth teasing out why this same spending isn‚Äôt spooking investors at Google or Nvidia, both of which had a great quarter. OpenAI is the biggest offender, spending the same amount with far less financial cushion than Meta. There really are concerns that we‚Äôre creating a bubble, and if we are, Meta‚Äôs core business will let it ride things out better than most. But if you ask Sam Altman why he‚Äôs spending hundreds of billions of dollars on compute, he‚Äôll tell you he‚Äôs operating one of the fastest growing consumer services in human history ‚Äî and one bringing in $20 billion a year in revenue. We can argue about how sustainable the growth rate is (that‚Äôs a separate blog post), but there really is a fast-growing product at the bottom of all the OpenAI hype. A fast-growing ARR figure goes a long way to answer questions. Meta doesn‚Äôt have a product like that, and it‚Äôs not clear where it‚Äôs going to come from. The company‚Äôs most powerful AI product is the Meta AI assistant, which Zuckerberg noted on the call has more than a billion active users. But those numbers are surely juiced by the three billion active users on Facebook and Instagram, and it‚Äôs hard to see the current version of Meta AI as a competitor to ChatGPT. There‚Äôs also the Vibes video generator, which really did boost daily active users, but has limited business impact beyond that. The most ambitious project is the Vanguard smart glasses released earlier this month. However, the glasses feel more like an extension of Meta‚Äôs Reality Labs work than a real attempt to harness the power of LLMs. Put simply, these are promising experiments, not fully formed products. It‚Äôs telling then that when he was pressed on infrastructure spending, Zuckerberg‚Äôs response wasn‚Äôt to point to the recent launches, but to focus on the next generation. Zuckerberg stressed, while emphasizing the pending impact of the Superintelligence Lab‚Äôs new models, that he was very excited about new products. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not just Meta AI as an assistant,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe expect to build novel models and novel products, and I‚Äôm excited to share more when we have it.‚Äù But this was an earnings call, not a product launch, so all he could say was that there would be more to share ‚Äúin the coming months.‚Äù As the market response showed that answer is wearing thin. To be fair, it‚Äôs only been four months since Zuckerberg restructured his company‚Äôs AI team, and the new Superintelligence team hasn‚Äôt had time to launch an earthshaking AI product yet. But as the company spends billions of dollars to stay competitive in AI, there‚Äôs still no clear indication of what role Zuckerberg wants to play in the new industry. Will Meta AI use the company‚Äôs detailed store of personal data to grow into a ChatGPT competitor? Is Vibes the first step in a consumer entertainment play, building off Meta‚Äôs targeted ad system? Or maybe Zuckerberg‚Äôs references to ‚Äúbusiness AI‚Äù are hints at a more detailed enterprise play? So far, it‚Äôs anyone‚Äôs guess. Whatever the answer, the pressure is on Meta to find it ‚Äî and soon. Topics AI Editor StrictlyVC concludes its 2025 series with an exclusive event featuring insights from leading VCs and builders, and opportunities to forge meaningful connections. Sam Altman says ‚Äòenough‚Äô to questions about OpenAI‚Äôs revenue Meta has an AI product problem AI researchers ‚Äôembodied‚Äô an LLM into a robot ‚Äì and it started channeling Robin Williams YouTube announces ‚Äòvoluntary exit program‚Äô for US staff Grammarly rebrands to ‚ÄòSuperhuman,‚Äô launches a new AI assistant VC Vinod Khosla says the US government could take 10% stake in all public companies to soften the blow of AGI OpenAI offers free ChatGPT Go for one year to all users in India ¬© 2025 TechCrunch Media LLC.

Title: From Wild West to Wall Street: Crypto is boring now because ‚Äòwe won‚Äô
URL: https://cryptoslate.com/from-wild-west-to-wall-street-crypto-is-boring-now-because-we-won/
Time Published: 2025-11-02T16:00:38Z
Full Content:
Once the Wild West of finance, crypto has matured into a Wall Street fixture with regulators and ETFs. We won. That‚Äôs why crypto is boring now. Cover art/illustration via CryptoSlate. Image includes combined content which may include AI-generated content. Remember when Crypto Twitter was like taking a front-row seat to the movies? Markets were a runaway rollercoaster, narratives flipped like pancakes, and every week had the energy of a new heist movie. What happened? If you‚Äôre lamenting the days of God candles and 20% BTC pumps, Nic Carter wants you to smile through the tears: crypto is boring now because we won. From major exchange collapses to China bans, Elon Musk pumps to COVID black swans, it‚Äôs been quite a ride. Jamie Dimon lambasted Bitcoin as a ‚Äúfraud‚Äù and threatened to fire anyone caught trading it at JPMorgan. Now the world‚Äôs biggest banks are stacking stablecoins, and even Dimon admits, ‚ÄúCrypto is real. Stablecoins are real,‚Äù as JPMorgan invites clients to post BTC and ETH as collateral for loans and launches its own blockchain rails. Are all the crazy days behind us now, and crypto is boring? Is it time to seek a new asset class for our thrills? Turns out, Gandhi‚Äôs saying, ‚Äúfirst they ignore you, then they laugh at you, then they fight you, then you win,‚Äù might fit crypto better than anyone expected.‚Äã At the heart of the vibe shift is what Nic Carter nailed in a post on X. The reason the volatility has dampened is because we won. As he states: ‚ÄúCrypto is boring because so many of the open questions have been answered.‚Äù Gone is the existential guessing game about whether stablecoins will be banned or if writing smart contracts will get you thrown in jail. The old school volatility, the kind that made fortunes and wiped them out by lunchtime, came straight from regulatory Russian roulette and the sense that rules might change at any moment.‚Äã Now? The GENIUS Act pins down rules for stablecoins, the Clarity Act sets out bright lines for what is a security and what isn‚Äôt. And even the question of crypto‚Äôs marriage with TradFi is a historical footnote, not a juicy risk premium. When you live in a world where holding T-bills on-chain is business casual and BlackRock‚Äôs ETF isn‚Äôt controversial, that means dampened volatility. Which means that crypto is boring. Even as price action grinds along, what used to be wild opportunity now feels, to many, like a playground being turned into a parking lot.‚Äã As BTC analyst Will Clemente commented: ‚ÄúThe vibes in the crypto groupchats that I‚Äôm in are just sad honestly, people completely giving up and pivoting to other asset classes if they haven‚Äôt already.‚Äù But Carter isn‚Äôt mourning. As he sees it, regulatory clarity, Wall Street adoption, and boring stability are proof that crypto won. The whole space has matured. What was once a technological risk-fest is now a ‚Äútechnological substrate‚Äù adopted by the world‚Äôs biggest firms. The new game isn‚Äôt about skirting the law; it‚Äôs about building products that actually generate value in clear daylight.‚Äã Wall Street didn‚Äôt just join the party; it put on the DJ headphones. BlackRock. JPMorgan. Even Jamie Dimon‚Äôs about-face is now crypto lore. From denier to builder, the old guard‚Äôs pivot closes the loop on a playbook that once prioritized chaos and rewarded pirates. Now, crypto is boring. TradFi‚Äôs seriousness brings real capital, real custody, and real infrastructure. The legends of the wild west are being replaced by compliance teams, pension allocators, and crash-helmeted bankers. And that‚Äôs all great‚Ä¶ except some of us miss the outlaws. This movie just feels like we‚Äôve seen it before. Christina is a web3 writer, editor, and content manager with a passion for technology and starting important conversations. As an industry OG, she‚Äôs not phased by market volatility and frequently scrimps on Starbucks to BTFD. Follow us on X for your essential dose of daily crypto news and deep dives. Title: China tweets satellite photos of Taiwan's critical Hsinchu chip hub in pressure-ratcheting political stunt ‚Äî 'where all the world‚Äôs advanced foundry IP is created,' highest concentration of chipmaking facilities in the world
URL: https://www.tomshardware.com/tech-industry/semiconductors/china-posts-photo-of-taiwans-chip-hub-in-political-message
Time Published: 2025-11-02T15:46:04Z
Full Content:
A Chinese embassy post highlighting Hsinchu Science Park underscores rising geopolitical risks to the world‚Äôs most advanced chip supply. When you purchase through links on our site, we may earn an affiliate commission. Here‚Äôs how it works. On Friday night, China‚Äôs embassy in Washington posted a familiar message to X: ‚ÄúThere is but one China in the world.‚Äù But this time, the predictable rhetoric from China came with a glossy photo carousel that included a sweeping aerial shot of Hsinchu Science Park, the epicenter of the world‚Äôs most advanced semiconductor manufacturing. As analyst Patrick Moorhead highlighted in a response to the embassy‚Äôs post, Hsinchu includes TSMC‚Äôs Fabs 12A, 12B, 20, 3, 5, 8, 2 and the Advanced Backend Fab 1, all crammed into the park‚Äôs core, along with the company‚Äôs Global R&D Center, ‚Äúwhere all the world‚Äôs advanced foundry IP is created,‚Äù he wrote, pointing out that chips for Nvidia, AMD, Apple, Qualcomm, and even Intel depends on this small square of land. There is but one #China in the world; #Taiwan is an inalienable part of China's territory. Every inch of Taiwan Province, China, is vibrant under the "Jilin-1" space satellite's perspective. üá®üá≥üá®üá≥üá®üá≥üíßSun Moon Lake Êó•ÊúàÊΩ≠‚õ∞Alishan ÈòøÈáåÂ±±üèôTaipei City Âè∞ÂåóÂ∏Ç‚öìÔ∏èTaipei Port Âè∞ÂåóÊ∏Ø‚Ä¶ pic.twitter.com/bOIvAdrSuyOctober 31, 2025 While the post didn‚Äôt mention chips directly, it didn‚Äôt have to. Hsinchu is home to TSMC‚Äôs original fabs, the headquarters of MediaTek and UMC, and key government agencies that oversee Taiwan‚Äôs space and chip strategy. There is no other place on Earth with the same concentration of cutting-edge logic process nodes. This is where the GPUs that train AI models begin, where desktop and server CPUs are etched, and where bleeding-edge silicon IP is designed. Expand the embedded tweet below to see the images. Let me be clearer. Here are the TSMC fabs currently in Hsinchu Science Park in Taiwan: Fab 12A/12B/20/3/5/8/2 and Advanced Backend Fab 1. Oh, and $TSM HQ and the ‚ÄúGlobal R&D Center‚Äù where all the world‚Äôs advanced foundry IP is created to build all $NVDA, $AMD, $AVGO, $AAPL,‚Ä¶ https://t.co/zpCTETPHKf pic.twitter.com/d0KiK19iYWNovember 1, 2025 This isn‚Äôt the first time that Beijing has tried to remind the world of Taiwan‚Äôs vulnerability. In recent months, Chinese naval forces have staged simulated blockades in the Taiwan Strait, inspecting commercial cargo ships and raising fears of a chokepoint disruption. The Trans-Pacific Express Cable System, which directly connects Taiwan to the U.S. East Coast, Japan, South Korea, and China, was damaged by a Cameroon-flagged freighter, Shunxing39, earlier this year, prompting Taiwan to increase legal penalties for damaging undersea cables. According to a recent special report from Reuters, U.S. officials have begun modeling worst-case scenarios for the Bashi Channel, a key shipping lane essential to Taiwanese exports like advanced wafers and electronics, in response to recent incursions. In September, the US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent called Taiwan‚Äôs chip sector the ‚Äúsingle greatest point of failure for the world economy‚Äù because 99% of high-performance chips are manufactured there, and back in June 2021, a White House review warned that even a temporary hit to TSMC output could ripple through everything from datacenters to defense. China‚Äôs embassy didn‚Äôt need to mention any of that directly. A single photo of Hsinchu was enough at a moment while tensions remain high. Oh, and $TSM HQ and the ‚ÄúGlobal R&D Center‚Äù where all the world‚Äôs advanced foundry IP is created to build all $NVDA, $AMD, $AVGO, $AAPL,‚Ä¶ https://t.co/zpCTETPHKf pic.twitter.com/d0KiK19iYWNovember 1, 2025 This isn‚Äôt the first time that Beijing has tried to remind the world of Taiwan‚Äôs vulnerability. In recent months, Chinese naval forces have staged simulated blockades in the Taiwan Strait, inspecting commercial cargo ships and raising fears of a chokepoint disruption. The Trans-Pacific Express Cable System, which directly connects Taiwan to the U.S. East Coast, Japan, South Korea, and China, was damaged by a Cameroon-flagged freighter, Shunxing39, earlier this year, prompting Taiwan to increase legal penalties for damaging undersea cables. According to a recent special report from Reuters, U.S. officials have begun modeling worst-case scenarios for the Bashi Channel, a key shipping lane essential to Taiwanese exports like advanced wafers and electronics, in response to recent incursions. In September, the US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent called Taiwan‚Äôs chip sector the ‚Äúsingle greatest point of failure for the world economy‚Äù because 99% of high-performance chips are manufactured there, and back in June 2021, a White House review warned that even a temporary hit to TSMC output could ripple through everything from datacenters to defense. China‚Äôs embassy didn‚Äôt need to mention any of that directly. A single photo of Hsinchu was enough at a moment while tensions remain high. Title: Why Millions Of Women Are Choosing Entrepreneurship In 2025
URL: https://www.forbes.com/sites/carolinecastrillon/2025/11/02/why-millions-of-women-are-choosing-entrepreneurship-in-2025/
Time Published: 2025-11-02T15:28:00Z
Full Content:
ByCaroline Castrillon, Senior Contributor. In 2024, women started nearly 1 of every 2 new businesses in America. That‚Äôs the highest rate on record, according to Gusto‚Äôs 2025 New Business Formation study. In addition, between 2019 and 2023, the number of women-owned businesses increased at nearly double the rate of their male counterparts, the 2024 Wells Fargo Impact of Women-Owned Business Report reveals. Women are leaving traditional corporate roles in unprecedented numbers to pursue entrepreneurship, writing their own rules for what success looks like. One example is April Springer, a former HR professional turned multi-unit business owner with Next Day Access, a provider of mobility and accessibility products. Based in Minneapolis, she owns three locations and also serves as vice president for the Minnesota and Pittsburgh territories. Her first location generated more than $1 million in revenue in its first year. She‚Äôs since expanded into multiple markets and now mentors other women in franchising. Her journey offers insights into the most powerful reasons millions of women are choosing entrepreneurship over corporate careers. The traditional corporate ladder no longer represents the pinnacle of achievement for many women. Success has become deeply personal, shaped by individual values rather than external expectations. As Springer explains, "I think women are redefining success on their own terms. There's no one-size-fits-all version of what a successful career or life looks like." This shift stems from: Expert Tip: Before making any major career move, write down your personal definition of success in specific, measurable terms. If you find yourself describing someone else's achievements or using vague terms, you haven't defined it yet. Your definition should be so clear you'd know instantly whether you're living it. Traditional employment models weren't built for modern life. More women are seeking careers that can adapt to their evolving priorities, whether that's family responsibilities, personal passions or the desire for autonomy over their schedules. As Springer explains, "The traditional corporate path doesn't always offer the flexibility, fulfillment or creativity many women are seeking. Entrepreneurship allows women to design a life and career that align with their values and priorities." What flexibility really means: Expert Tip: Track your energy and productivity patterns for two weeks. If your current job structure conflicts with your natural rhythms and priorities more than 60% of the time, that's a signal that entrepreneurship might serve you better. The rise of social media has transformed how women view entrepreneurship. Platforms like Instagram, LinkedIn and TikTok showcase real stories of women building successful businesses, making the path to entrepreneurship feel more accessible than ever before. Springer notes the impact of this visibility, "Social media has also played a big role in this shift. When women see others building successful businesses and balancing life in ways that inspire them, it creates momentum." The digital community effect includes: Expert Tip: Follow 10-15 women entrepreneurs in your industry on social media. Don't just scroll‚Äîactively engage. Comment on their posts, ask questions and join conversations. The connections you build digitally often translate into real mentorship and support when you launch your own venture. For women who want to be their own boss but feel intimidated by starting from scratch, franchising presents a compelling middle ground. Franchise models provide proven systems, established branding and built-in support networks that significantly reduce the risk associated with new business ventures. The franchise advantage includes: Expert Tip: Before investing in any franchise, speak with at least five current franchisees you choose yourself‚Äînot the ones referred by the franchisor. Ask specifically about hidden costs, actual time commitments and whether they'd make the same choice again. Many women entrepreneurs aren‚Äôt just chasing profits. They‚Äôre building small businesses with purpose. The desire to create meaningful impact drives many women to leave stable corporate positions for the uncertainty of entrepreneurship. Mission-driven businesses benefit from: Expert Tip: Define your business mission in one sentence: "We help [specific people] achieve [specific outcome] so they can [meaningful benefit]." If you struggle to complete this sentence clearly, spend more time refining your purpose. A vague mission won't sustain you through entrepreneurship's challenges. Amazon recently announced 14,000 corporate job cuts, while Target eliminated 1,000 roles. Entire departments can disappear overnight due to restructuring, automation or economic shifts. For many women, entrepreneurship offers more control over their financial future than any corporate job ever could. When you own your business, your income depends on your own efforts, not on someone else's decision to cut headcount. Why women are choosing entrepreneurship over corporate jobs: Expert Tip: If you're concerned about leaving your corporate job, start your business as a side hustle while still employed. Test your concept, build a client base and validate your income potential before making the leap. Many successful entrepreneurs launch this way, reducing risk while proving their business model works. The millions of women pursuing entrepreneurship today aren't abandoning ambition. They're redefining it on their own terms. It proves the best career path isn‚Äôt always the one laid out by someone else. Often, it‚Äôs the one you build yourself. Enjoyed this article?I share weekly cheat sheets, tools and inspiration to help professionals escape burnout, make confident career changes and design work that feels purposeful. üëâ Join 10,000+ professionals building freedom and fulfillment at work

Title: 'Bitcoin's Silent IPO': Analyst Addresses BTC's Lame Price Action in Viral Weekend Essay
URL: https://www.coindesk.com/markets/2025/11/02/bitcoin-s-silent-ipo-analyst-addresses-btc-s-lame-price-action-in-viral-weekend-essay
Time Published: 2025-11-02T14:40:47Z
Full Content:
It's not exactly news to frustrated bitcoin BTC$107,661.53 bulls that risk assets across the planet for months have been recording what seem like daily record highs while the price action in BTC remains rather muted. "What if everyone is looking at this wrong," asks longtime traditional finance asset manager Jordi Visser in a heavily shared (1.5M views on X and counting) weekend essay titled "Bitcoin‚Äôs Silent IPO: Why This Consolidation Isn‚Äôt What You Think." While bitcoin never had a traditional IPO, the factors liming price gains are nearly exactly the same as those which cause poor price performance in stock IPOs, argues Visser. Tradfi IPOs and the months that follow, reminds Visser ‚Äî particularly in tech ‚Äî are major liquidity events for early investors. "Early-stage investors take enormous risks," wrote Visser. "If the investment succeeds, they deserve enormous rewards. But eventually, and this is crucial, they need to realize those gains. They need liquidity. They need an exit. They need to diversify." The examples, particularly in tech, are legion, but consider the Facebook (now Meta) IPO of 2012. The offering at $38 per share raised $16 billion at a valuation of $104 billion ‚Äî quaint numbers today, but staggering amounts at the time. One year later, the stock was 30% lower, with pundits questioning Mark Zuckerberg's leadership. More likely than missteps by Zuck, it was early investors ‚Äî be they his Harvard buddies, or Silicon Valley types, or the carpenters who framed out Facebook's first offices (who took pay in shares rather than cash) ‚Äî using public markets to realize life-changing profits. Importantly, says Visser, the early investors don't hit the bid all at once. "They‚Äôre methodically distributing their positions. They‚Äôre being careful. They don‚Äôt want to crater the price. They‚Äôre patient. They‚Äôve waited years for this moment. They can wait a few more months to do it right." The result, he says: "A sideways grind that drives everyone crazy." Sound familiar? "The on-chain data tells a clear story if you know how to read it," says Visser, turning to bitcoin. "Old coins, coins that haven‚Äôt moved in years, some dormant since the single-digit price days, are suddenly active." The ETFs, the institutional adoption, the friendly regulatory environment ... this created IPO-like conditions for bitcoin's early believers. "For years, the liquidity simply didn‚Äôt exist," he wrote. "Try selling $100 million of bitcoin in 2015. You‚Äôd crater the price. Try selling $1 billion in 2019. Same problem. The market couldn‚Äôt absorb it." "But now," he continued. "ETFs are providing institutional bid. Major companies hold bitcoin on their balance sheets. Sovereign wealth funds are getting involved. The market has finally matured to the point where early holders can exit significant positions without causing chaos." Again, reminds Visser, it's not being done all at once ‚Äî no one is interested in crashing the price. But instead, steadily and methodically: hence the sideways grind and the rallies that reverse so quickly. What's occurring now is hardly anything that can be called a bear market, says Visser, but instead a distribution of ownership. Over the long run, this is a bullish event, but the process ‚Äî at least in traditional markets ‚Äî can take 6-18 months. Even though cycles often get sped up in crypto, Visser suspects there could be many more months of this frustrating price action in bitcoin. "Sentiment will only improve after the distribution is substantially complete," he wrote. "People are demoralized because they don‚Äôt understand what phase we‚Äôre in. They‚Äôre waiting for bitcoin to 'catch up' to stocks. They are worried about the four year cycle. Be patient. Once the heavy selling pressure lifts, once the patient accumulation by institutions has absorbed the OG supply, the path becomes clearer." More For You OwlTing: Stablecoin Infrastructure for the Future Stablecoin payment volumes have grown to $19.4B year-to-date in 2025. OwlTing aims to capture this market by developing payment infrastructure that processes transactions in seconds for fractions of a cent. More For You ASTER Zooms 20% as Binance's CZ Purchases 2M Tokens ASTER is a rebranded derivative platform token with a max supply of 8 billion, focusing on community incentives and decentralized exchange features. Title: You can spot the hidden signs if your company is heading for layoffs. Smart moves to save your career before it is too late
URL: https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/magazines/panache/you-can-spot-the-hidden-signs-if-your-company-is-heading-for-layoffs-smart-moves-to-save-your-career-before-it-is-too-late/articleshow/125035231.cms
Time Published: 2025-11-02T14:17:45Z
Full Content:
Experts warn that layoffs rarely happen without warning signs. Employees can often detect trouble through hiring slowdowns, budget cuts, and shifts in company tone. HR consultants note that AI adoption and year-end cost reviews are fueling workforce reductions. Subtle cues like ‚Äúquiet firing‚Äù and return-to-office mandates may signal deeper cuts ahead. Title: The end of labour hoarding: How corporate America‚Äôs new ruthlessness signals a turning point

Title: When the wrench comes for the wallet: Why Bitcoin‚Äôs biggest believers are handing over their keys
URL: https://cryptoslate.com/when-the-wrench-comes-for-the-wallet-why-bitcoins-biggest-believers-are-handing-over-their-keys/
Time Published: 2025-11-02T14:00:17Z
Full Content:
Self-custody is under fire as wrench attacks become a real threat for crypto holders, with physical coercion and organized crime targeting those with on-chain wealth. Cover art/illustration via CryptoSlate. Image includes combined content which may include AI-generated content. Welcome to Slate Sunday, CryptoSlate‚Äôs weekly feature showcasing in-depth interviews, expert analysis, and thought-provoking op-eds that go beyond the headlines to explore the ideas and voices shaping the future of crypto. Self‚Äëcustody was once the ultimate badge of credibility in crypto. A declaration of faith in sovereignty over convenience, code over blind trust, and cryptography over legal fine print. But for many of the space‚Äôs earliest and wealthiest adopters, that belief is starting to bend under a different kind of pressure: wrench attacks. In a world now flush with organized crime, doxxing, and $5 wrench attacks, even the most battle‚Äëhardened Bitcoiners are locking away more than their coins; their ideology is going in the vault as well. A decade ago, wrench attack jokes circulated mostly in privacy forums. The meme, coined from a 2015 XKCD comic, encapsulates a brutal truth. You can‚Äôt brute‚Äëforce a passphrase, but you can threaten someone with a $5 wrench until they tell you it. OG Bitcoiner Jameson Lopp, co‚Äëfounder of Casa and maintainer of the ‚ÄúPhysical Bitcoin Attacks‚Äù directory, has spent years documenting cases of wrench attacks where everyday crypto holders are beaten, held hostage, or worse because of their on‚Äëchain visibility. The directory now lists more than 200 verified incidents spanning at least 34 countries. From European traders kidnapped at gunpoint to influencers targeted after posting wealth flexes online. As of October 2025, the directory records 52 wrench attacks this year alone (more than one per week), with overall physical assaults increasing 169% since February. In late October 2025, Russian influencer Sergei Domogatskii was kidnapped in Bali by masked assailants who tased and beat him, forcing him to transfer approximately $4,600 in crypto from his mobile phone to their accounts. This is part of a rising trend of wrench attacks in this region, as Lopp previously told me: ‚ÄúI‚Äôve seen a number of attacks, for example, where Russian citizens who are either vacationing or living in Southeast Asia are getting hit by Russian organized crime. They‚Äôre coming into the country, wrench attacking them, and then trying to get out as quickly as possible, and presumably trying to leverage jurisdictional arbitrage.‚Äù Even veteran cypherpunks are taking notice. In a recent interview on What Bitcoin Did, on‚Äëchain analyst Willy Woo admitted: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not self‚Äëcustodying anymore‚Ä¶ I think you‚Äôll see a lot more people who‚Äôve been in this space a long time doing the same.‚Äù Woo reinforced that smaller holders should absolutely keep control of their own coins, but large balances and public profiles create an entirely different threat model. It‚Äôs not about losing a hardware wallet anymore; it‚Äôs about personal safety. Many others share his view. The Bitcoin Family, known for selling everything to live off Bitcoin, told CNBC in June that they‚Äôve abandoned single‚Äëdevice wallets for a scattered analog‚Äëdigital fortress. They‚Äôve split seed phrases and encrypted data across four continents. Family patriarch Didi Taihuttu said: ‚ÄúEven if someone held me at gunpoint, I can‚Äôt give them more than what‚Äôs on my wallet or my phone. And that‚Äôs not a lot.‚Äù Both Woo and Taihuttu were once among the poster children for full sovereignty. Their quiet retreat marks a broader sentiment shift (one now confirmed by the numbers). Somehow, Wall Street has managed to do what few thought possible: lure long-time Bitcoin whales into its regulated fold. According to a recent Bloomberg article, a new breed of discreet, ultra-wealthy holders is quietly offloading their cold wallets and moving billions into spot ETFs (sometimes without so much as a murmur on the blockchain). Thanks to ‚Äúin-kind transfers,‚Äù these whales can dodge a taxable sale, swapping their BTC directly for ETF shares. BlackRock alone has taken in over $3 billion since July through this channel. Suddenly, what used to be a wild-west game of keys and ledgers is starting to look a lot more like traditional finance. All packaged up with a shiny ticker symbol and plenty of paperwork to go around. ‚ÄúThis terrified me a bit,‚Äù commented Bitcoin advocate and human rights activist Alex Gladstein. For someone who‚Äôs spent his career documenting the way repressive regimes freeze assets and lock citizens out of the global financial system, watching Bitcoin drift toward mainstream financial custody feels like watching the escape hatch slowly close. Why? Because safety, reporting, and inheritance are finally trumping ideology. Srbuhi Avetisyan, research and analytics lead at Owner.One and co‚Äëauthor of Penguin Analytics recently helped analyze 13,500 high‚Äënet‚Äëworth families across 18 countries. She shares: ‚ÄúAt high balances, the risk isn‚Äôt blockchain failure‚Äîit‚Äôs physical coercion and OPSEC drift (lost seeds, single-point wallets). 87% of families keep incomplete asset records, and 99.4% lack a verified digital twin of their holdings. Crypto often disappears at incapacity/death‚Äînot from volatility, but from missing credentials and unclear rights.‚Äù For these families, ETFs and qualified custodians aren‚Äôt about giving in to TradFi. They‚Äôre about ensuring heirs can locate and transfer what might otherwise vanish. Still, not everyone‚Äôs ready to hand the entire stack back to banks. There‚Äôs a rising class of ‚Äúhybrid‚Äù custodians building bridges between full self‚Äësovereignty and institutional protection. Seth for Privacy, vice president of the self‚Äëcustodial app Cake Wallet, says the wrench attacks problem doesn‚Äôt have to end self‚Äëcustody; it just forces it to evolve. He explains: ‚ÄúCrypto has become mainstream, and self-custody solutions have to keep up.‚Äù Beyond leveraging privacy tools, like Silent Payments and Payjoin, where possible, to keep their transactions out of public view, he believes the best protection for high‚Äëprofile individuals is to stop talking about their wealth. That was a point hammered home by Lopp, as well, who told me: ‚ÄúIf you are on any sort of public network and you are flaunting your wealth, that‚Äôs one of the more risky things that you could be doing.‚Äù Seth points to Lopp‚Äôs company, Casa, Unchained, or some newer entrants like Nunchuk and Liana as examples of ‚Äúcollaborative custody.‚Äù These setups enable users to maintain control while distributing risk through multi‚Äësignature arrangements, such as a 2‚Äëof‚Äë3 or 3‚Äëof‚Äë5 scheme, with a fiduciary or geographically separate co‚Äësigner to remove the single point of failure. Anthony Yeung, chief commercial officer at CoinCover, also sees hybrid models as the pragmatic path forward. ‚ÄúComplete independence also comes with risk. If a private key is lost or compromised, the assets are often gone forever. A hybrid model addresses this by combining the best of both worlds: individuals retain direct control and ownership of their assets, while a trusted institution provides a safety net through secure backup and recovery mechanisms.‚Äù He calls this ‚Äúa digital Fort Knox‚Äù: still user‚Äëcontrolled, but institutionalized enough to enable secure backups, key recovery, and even inheritance triggers. Yeung adds: ‚ÄúThey may well be the bridge that brings the next generation of users from web2 to web3.‚Äù Thomas Chen, CEO of Function and managing director at BitGo for six years, agrees, although he emphasizes personalization and risk tolerance. ‚ÄúI think a future for hybrid models ultimately depends on the user‚Äôs risk profile and what they‚Äôre comfortable with.‚Äù Those who self‚Äëcustody gain sovereignty but lose convenience, he says, particularly when they want to pledge assets as collateral, trade at scale, or interact with smart contracts in general. That‚Äôs not the experience that institutional investors want, and it may not be right for HNW individuals either. ETFs and custodial structures allow Bitcoin to act like a financial asset, not just a collectible. For institutions, that‚Äôs non‚Äënegotiable. As Andrew Gibb, CEO of Twinstake institutional-grade, non-custodial staking platform, put it: ‚ÄúThe custody landscape is shifting from the crypto-native ideal of total self-control toward models that match the risk appetite and operational rigor of institutional investors.‚Äù Fiduciary duty, in his view, forbids relying on untested personal key setups. Yet not everyone‚Äôs convinced this convenience is worth the compromise. Tony Yazbeck, co‚Äëfounder of The Bitcoin Way, offers a sharper take: ‚ÄúPeople love to overcomplicate this, but it really comes down to common sense. Some wealthy holders and institutions convince themselves they are safer putting their Bitcoin into ETFs or custodial accounts. They say it protects them from mistakes, inheritance issues, or even physical threats. In reality, it just hands control of the world‚Äôs scarcest asset to someone else and replaces ownership with paperwork.‚Äù Having lived through Lebanon‚Äôs banking collapse, Yazbeck warns that history has proven that third parties fail, exchanges collapse, governments seize assets, and custodians freeze withdrawals. His advice is refreshingly non‚Äëtechnical. ‚ÄúThe risk of losing your Bitcoin because you trusted a middleman is far higher than the risk of losing access to your own keys if you handle them properly. Multisig setups, secure backups, and simple operational discipline solve almost every real self-custody problem.‚Äù But the best defense? Once again, stop attracting attention to yourself. ‚ÄúStay quiet about what you hold and live a normal life.‚Äù His mantra: protect privacy, take responsibility, and never outsource what Bitcoin was invented to make trustless. EY blockchain specialist Yaniv Sofer believes we‚Äôre witnessing a financial re‚Äëtiering rather than an ideological rupture. He explains: ‚ÄúFinancial institutions are accelerating their entry into digital assets use cases, and custody is a critical core capability.‚Äù While some firms buy access through third‚Äëparty providers like Fireblocks and BitGo, others build internal systems to integrate tokenization and payments. Sofer cautions: ‚ÄúHybrid custody models have not yet gained significant traction among financial institutions but remain a topic of interest. Regulatory requirements for qualified custodians continue to favor centralized solutions‚Ä¶ but hybrid models could emerge as a differentiator as the market matures.‚Äù In Avetisyan‚Äôs view, the long‚Äëterm equilibrium is clear. Most founders will run dual rails: core exposure in ETFs or qualified custody for reporting and collateralization, with a smaller self‚Äëcustody satellite for censorship resistance. This dual-rail system, she says, is already shifting how liquidity flows through the crypto economy. As more Bitcoin migrates to custodial wrappers, traditional funding markets gain depth and stability. The flip side? Sovereignty becomes optional, not default. Maybe what‚Äôs happening now isn‚Äôt so much an ideological defeat as a maturation. Bitcoin‚Äôs promise of self‚Äësovereignty remains intact for those who choose to uphold it. As the Bitcoin lead at Sygnum Bank, Pascal Eberle, comments: ‚ÄúThe future of ‚ÄúFreedom Money‚Äù lies in choice ‚Äì investors can opt for full self-custody, institutional-grade protection, or hybrid models that balance both.‚Äù Hybrid custody, institutional wrappers, and ETF liquidity are all symptoms of the same evolution: crypto crossing into the realm of structured finance. For early believers, that can feel like a betrayal, with self-custody becoming sidelined to the margins. As Yazbeck framed it: ‚ÄúThinking you are safer by giving your Bitcoin to someone else is like a rich person surrounding themselves with a military convoy out of paranoia. It looks strong but it is actually weak.‚Äù Yet perhaps this is decentralization in action; a dispersion of risk, trust, and control according to every individual‚Äôs appetite. Each generation of holder must redraw its own line between freedom and fear. In 2025, that line runs straight through the vault door. Title: How Fintech Is Redefining Retirement Planning For The Private Markets Era
URL: https://www.forbes.com/sites/ilonalimonta-volkova/2025/11/02/how-fintech-is-redefining-retirement-planning-for-the-private-markets-era/
Time Published: 2025-11-02T14:00:00Z
Full Content:
ByIlona Limonta-Volkova, Contributor. Most Americans are preparing for retirement with yesterday‚Äôs tools. The rules of retirement planning are changing, but few have noticed. Financial innovation often promises greater access and equality, yet adoption rarely keeps pace with aspiration. A recent Harris Poll found that nearly 40% of Americans have never heard of private-credit funds, a class of alternative investments that Wall Street is racing to bring to 401(k)s. Only 10% say they want more nontraditional options in their retirement accounts. Yet once investors learn that most U.S. businesses generating over $100 million in annual revenue are privately held, nearly 60% say they would consider investing in them, and 90% would allocate part of their savings to private markets. It is not that Americans do not want these investments. They just do not know they exist. The disconnect between awareness and appetite points to a fundamental problem: the infrastructure to connect regular investors with private credit simply has not existed until recently. For decades, these investments remained locked behind institutional walls, accessible only to pension funds, endowments, and the ultra-wealthy. That is changing as technology platforms modernize an industry that has historically run on spreadsheets and handshakes. "Private credit shouldn‚Äôt be a black box," asserts Nelson Chu, co-founder and president of Percent, a fintech platform democratizing access to private credit markets. His company is one of several working to crack open what has long been an opaque, insider-only market. "By standardizing issuance and surfacing live order books and post-close surveillance, we've opened a historically institutional market to accredited investors with shorter durations, lower minimums, and clearer visibility into risk and cash flows." What Chu describes addresses one of the biggest obstacles to bringing these investments mainstream: transparency. Traditional private credit deals are typically opaque, illiquid, and require enormous capital commitments. Modern platforms are changing the equation by building digital infrastructure that brings efficiency and visibility to previously murky markets. This matters for a simple reason: 401(k) investors have watched their investment options narrow as the number of publicly traded companies has declined. Private markets now represent a vast universe of investment opportunities that most retirement savers cannot touch, even as their pension fund counterparts have loaded up on these assets for years. The irony is hard to miss. The investments deemed suitable for public pension funds are considered too risky or complex for the individuals those pensions serve. Earlier this year, federal agencies were mandated to ease regulations around alternative investments in retirement plans signals momentum toward broader access. Major asset managers, like Apollo and BlackRock, are already positioning themselves to capture a share of the $13 trillion 401(k) market. The race is on. Success will likely not come from regulatory approval alone. It will require building investor confidence through education and infrastructure. Companies like Percent in the U.S. and Germany's Exaloan are demonstrating that private credit can operate with the same transparency and efficiency that investors expect from their brokerage accounts. Exaloan provides data infrastructure and analytics that enable banks and asset managers to originate, assess, and monitor private debt portfolios with institutional-grade transparency. By digitizing loan-level data and standardizing reporting, platforms like these are proving that private credit can operate with the same clarity and efficiency investors expect from their brokerage accounts. "Retail investor appetite for alternative assets has accelerated dramatically," Chu explains. "We're seeing sophisticated investors, business owners, executives, professionals, actively seeking diversification beyond the 60/40 portfolio. They want assets that don't correlate with public markets, are designed to generate cash flow, and offer transparency into what they're investing in." The question is no longer whether these assets will enter 401(k) plans. It is how fast the system can catch up. The technology is in place, and investor appetite is undeniable. What remains is closing the knowledge gap and creating the transparency that builds lasting trust. This has the potential to redefine retirement planning. And for millions of Americans, that shift cannot happen fast enough.
--------------------------------------------------

URL: https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/tech/artificial-intelligence/nadella-says-microsoft-will-hire-again-but-with-an-ai-first-approach/articleshow/125032794.cms
Time Published: 2025-11-02T12:32:08Z
Full Content:
(Catch all the Technology News News, and Latest News Updates on The Economic Times.) ...more Popular Categories Hot on Web In Case you missed it Top Searched Companies Other useful Links Top Calculators Top Prime Articles Top Slideshow Top Definitions Top Story Listing Private Companies Top Commodities Top Market Pages Latest News follow us on Download ET App:

Title: S&P 500 Q3 2025 Earnings Surge: Magnificent 7 Lead Market Rally
URL: https://www.forbes.com/sites/bill_stone/2025/11/02/sp-500-q3-2025-earnings-surge-magnificent-7-lead-market-rally/
Time Published: 2025-11-02T12:24:46Z
Full Content:
ByBill Stone, Contributor. The third-quarter earnings season begins its second busiest week, with 135 S&P 500 companies scheduled to report. Notable companies scheduled to release earnings include: Palantir (PLTR), Pfizer (PFE), Yum! Brands (YUM), Emerson Electric (EMR), McDonald‚Äôs (MCD), Humana (HUM), and Qualcomm (QCOM). Warren Buffett‚Äôs Berkshire Hathaway (BRK/A, BRK/B) reported better-than-expected earnings on Saturday. A deeper dive and insights into Berkshire Hathaway‚Äôs third-quarter earnings are here. With 64% of companies reporting so far, 83% have beaten consensus earnings estimates. The earnings season preview from last week contains more details about the underlying drivers of earnings. Combining actual results with consensus estimates for companies yet to report, the S&P 500‚Äôs blended earnings growth rate for the quarter is at 10.7% year-over-year, above the expectations of 7.9% at the end of the quarter. The expected earnings growth rates for calendar years 2025 and 2026 increased to 11.2% and 14.0%, respectively. The continuation of the strong earnings season helped lift the S&P 500 last week. The Magnificent 7, consisting of Microsoft (MSFT), Meta Platforms (META), Amazon.com (AMZN), Apple (AAPL), NVIDIA (NVDA), Alphabet (GOOGL), and Tesla (TSLA), outperformed last week. Because these companies are critical drivers of earnings growth and a significant percentage of the S&P 500‚Äôs market capitalization, the Magnificent 7 remained the group to watch this earnings season. Despite the disappointments from Tesla (TSLA) and Meta Platforms (META), the rest of the group picked up the slack. Alphabet (GOOGL), Microsoft (MSFT), and Amazon.com (AMZN) continued to support the thesis that demand for artificial intelligence (AI) is driving robust growth. Meta Platforms (META) posted disappointing headline earnings due to a non-cash tax charge. More importantly, investors were spooked by the announcement of more than $100 billion in planned investments in AI next year. As a positive, third-quarter revenues grew 26% year over year, and their ad business continues to post impressive results, so the underlying business remains robust. NVIDIA (NVDA), the last of the Magnificent 7 to report earnings, is scheduled to report on November 19. According to FactSet data, the positive earnings surprises from companies in the information technology, consumer discretionary, and health care sectors were the most significant contributors to the S&P 500‚Äôs earnings growth rate increase last week. As detailed above, the communication services sector was the largest detractor due to Meta‚Äôs earnings miss. Within technology, Microsoft (MSFT) and Apple (AAPL) were the most significant positive drivers. Amazon.com (AMZN) was the most crucial positive surprise in consumer discretionary, while Eli Lilly (LLY), Merck (MRK), and Gilead Sciences (GILD) were the most notable positive surprises in health care. Sales growth at 7.9% is running well above expectations. Three sectors are on pace for double-digit year-over-year sales growth this quarter: information technology, communication services, and health care. With the government shutdown continuing to drag on, US economic releases should remain relatively sparse. Importantly, the widely watched monthly jobs report is likely to be delayed by the government closure. Instead, the private ADP employment change release on Wednesday and the Challenger job-cut announcement report on Thursday will attract more attention than usual as investors and economists gauge the softness of the US labor market. Third-quarter earnings reports will fill the void during the second busiest reporting week of the season. While a better-than-expected earnings season is all but assured, the individual company reports and any commentary about future earnings expectations remain crucial. As widely anticipated, the Federal Reserve (Fed) delivered a 25 basis point (0.25%) rate cut at its meeting last Wednesday. Fed Chair Powell pushed back harder than expected against the market expectations of another cut at the December meeting, sending the odds to a little less than a 2-in-3 chance. The calendar is chock-full of Fed members speaking this week, so their comments will be closely monitored to gauge better the likelihood of a Fed easing in December. Disclosure: Glenview Trust may hold the stocks mentioned in this article within its recommended investment strategies.
--------------------------------------------------

I don‚Äôt know why people become serial killers nor do I even care. I only know what should be done with them ‚Äì and with extreme prejudice. ‚ÄúWhy are we obsessed with serial killers?‚Äù Maybe because the killer in me is the killer in you‚Ä¶. Disarm, by Billy Corgan So I‚Äôve watched a few of these series below on the central villain, and there is overlap of a kind, like deciphering whether the cult leader( ie, Jeffs ) or the serial killer is actually the worse and more effective evil. Exerting control seems to be a recurring theme. ‚Äì Jeffrey Dahmer ‚Äì Warren Jeffs and the FLDS cult ( polygamy ) ‚Äì Ted Bundy ‚Äì John Wayne Gacy ‚Äì Zodiac These are all dark, and highly disturbing. I include the last entry since per the film, released in 2007 and possibly overlooked then, the alleged murderer was never actually caught or arrested for his crimes. My conclusion‚Ä¶some people are just not wired correctly from the get to. I actually have been a little curious about what the big deal is. Where I live, gang members have tens of bodies under their belts. There‚Äôre also a whole host of famous people who should be called serial killers but aren‚Äôt, like Obama. As far as I can tell, the only difference is that they lack individual notoriety for their crimes, for one reason or the other. The article doesn‚Äôt address this at all, unless I missed it and I would agree that the author‚Äôs reported curiousity may be less ubiquitous than they believe. It seems to me like the fascination with learning how other persons met with a miserable end is a phenomenom driven by news outlets (traditional and novel) hyping up particularly unique cases as a relatively easy sell for views/clicks etc.. The difference in the treatment is just stark. My news is always filled with the more prolific of the twenty or so deaths over the last week, sometimes barely afforded a paragraph because it‚Äôs the same old story over and over. Even when bodies do get found in pieces it‚Äôs not particularly earth-shattering. As far as I can tell, it seems to be that having a hundred known victims can never live up to the hype of leaving three of four bodies in sculpted positions. ‚ÄòSlasher‚Äô enthusiasts, I‚Äôm sure, hardly care to learn how Joe went from selling his body for food to doing his part, keeping morticians securely employed. Mass murderers, spree killers, serial killers are categories, but I guess the category closest to covering officially protected perps would be something like ‚Äústate sponsorsed terrorism‚Äù. US media is obsessed with serial killers (‚Äòwe‚Äô means them), because shocking content attracts audience. It‚Äôs softcore atrocity porn. A polarizing film but one I think captured this well was Oliver Stone‚Äôs ‚ÄúNatural Born Killers‚Äù. It‚Äôs too graphic and psychedelic for some but the way it portrays the media hype and popular fandom around a duo of serial killers was phenomenal in my opinion. Takes the old adage of ‚ÄúIf it bleeds, it leads‚Äù and turned the dial up to eleven to critique the 90‚Äôs era tabloid news like Hard Copy. Not sure if there are any modern equivalents but to me that film still holds up and remains relevant. In an awful comparison, serial killers are tantamount to aces in that you need 5 kills to establish yourself as such. Note to gun nuts intent on doing your worst: Any outcome in the single-digits is pretty much yeah whatever as far as Presstidigitation is concerned. It might not even make the front page of the internet-such is fate. By serial killers, do they mean social murders? Kills more people than any serial killer ever has. On the AI front, this below in today‚Äôs FT reporting the same thing that commenter Rasperry Jam has been saying, that much of AI‚Äôs immediate future is in specialized foundation models using proprietary data. . No archived link yet ‚Äî https://www.ft.com/content/91002071-7874-4cb7-9245-08ca0571c408 The new hot job in AI: forward-deployed engineers OpenAI, Anthropic and Cohere have stepped up hiring for specialists to help businesses adopt their AI models ‚Äò‚Ä¶Anthropic, OpenAI and Cohere are recruiting for so-called forward-deployed engineers, a new job for generative AI companies, as part of a push to generate more revenues by installing specialists within businesses to help them customise their AI models‚Ä¶. ‚Äò‚Ä¶The move comes as businesses across industries from manufacturing to healthcare are increasingly keen to adopt AI tools, but are often unsure how to use the technology and generate a return on investment. ‚ÄúA Fortune 500 bank has completely different needs than a start-up building an AI-native product,‚Äù said Cat de Jong, head of applied AI at Anthropic ‚Ä¶. ‚ÄòWhile FDEs (forward-deployed engineers) represent a relatively small number of AI groups‚Äô workforce, OpenAI said demand for these roles has exceeded its expectations. ‚ÄòThe group used this approach to customise its technology for John Deere, an agricultural machinery manufacturer, to help create more precise farming tools. This resulted in farmers reducing chemical spraying by 60 per cent to 70 per cent. ‚ÄòOpenAI‚Äôs Fournier said: ‚ÄúWe learn what customers in different industries really need, we experiment and innovate together, and then those insights help advance OpenAI‚Äôs research and product offerings based on what works in the real world.‚Äù Me: This is AI coming for McKinsey, Bain, and the like. i.e. Customers used to contract with a management consultancy firm, which then outourced a majority of work to an IT consultancy firm (ITF) that in turn might do 90% of work for 10% of contract value and the MCF took the rest. Any true value lay in which ITF the management consultant firm had the nous to choose. With AI, the ITF ‚Äî in this case, OpenAI, Anthropic, whichever‚Äì disintermediates McKinsey etc. and assigns their role to its own forward development engineers. So if those forward-deployed engineers are working with a Fortune 500 bank or a corporation like John Deere to tailor those AIs to them individually, would it also work out that they would also be funneling those corporation‚Äôs vital information back to Anthropic, OpenAI and Cohere for use as training set data? Yup. One thought, suppose there are better, more efficient AI models than Anthropic or Claude, buying into solution before problem‚Ä¶. Don‚Äôt rule out consulting yet. How about small language modules? Open labs* are raining small language models right now, some under 1B parameters, which is small enough to work (with patience) on any laptop. Most recently, LiquidAI published open-weight small models specialized for retrieval-augmented generation, summarization, information extraction, and mathematics. There has been a lot of recent work in vision and OCR surfacing recently as well. Small models are becoming more capable and efficient not only to encode or translate the text of a page or sign or describe a photo, but correctly read and reproduce sparse tables or describe the actions occurring between two video frames (with bounding boxes). * By open labs I mean those whose corporate future is not dependent on a world where all inference is centralized in a proprietary cloud, and who are not so motivated to hoard their IP or models. OpenAI and Anthropic, contrariwise, are worthless unless they can force the Western world to channel all its mechanical language processing through their machines and their meters. I think of OpenAI and Anthropic much like Uber, as regulatory plays intending to construct a regulatory environment in which the highly moderated service they offer is socially necessary, and alternatives are rendered illegal, unmerchantable, or impossible. Reminder that the ‚Äúanti‚Äù-AI movement is only a shaping operation in the larger war against local computation, and, being mainly funded and operated by US AI services majors, national security goons, and washed-up pundits trying to uphold a lifestyle, should only ever be held with the same absolute suspicion and cynical hostility as any other corporate astroturf. The myth is not entirely wrong for some health conditions. My mother-in-law had polio as an infant. At some point in her seventies and eighties she (and the medical profession discovered that her muscles only had so many contractions in them and that the exercises she had been doing to maintain her strength were weakening her. would it also work out that they would also be funneling those corporation‚Äôs vital information back to Anthropic, OpenAI and Cohere for use as training set data? Typically legal agreements are signed between the model provider and the company purchasing the services that the purchaser‚Äôs proprietary data, code, trade-protected processes ‚Äì anything that falls under IP ‚Äì remains under the control of the purchaser and is not the property of the model provider. What this means in practice is more nuanced: these companies are hiring the FDE‚Äôs as part of a service to create fine-tuned models trained on the customer‚Äôs data and processes, for exclusive use by the purchasing company. I‚Äôve worked on projects like this for my company; we didn‚Äôt have access to the customer‚Äôs IP directly. What we did was brought in the trainer application(s), taught the purchasing customer how to train their model, and provided guidance on how to configure, evaluate and deploy it after it was complete. We also taught them how to prompt/interact with the models based on what they were trying to do. We ‚Äì and likely these other model providers ‚Äì provide the purchasing company with the model trainer because taking the customer‚Äôs IP out of their network is a) probably too much data, I‚Äôm talking in excess of 50 terabytes b) no company‚Äôs security team is going to sign off on that no matter how lucrative/cool the end use case will be. So no, they probably aren‚Äôt taking the customer‚Äôs IP and sending it back to the primary frontier models for training in the way you are describing. They‚Äôre making a smaller version of the frontier model trained on the customer‚Äôs IP, for the customer‚Äôs exclusive use. The FDE are running the training and internal education projects. Sounds like Lean Six Sigma ‚Äúblack belts‚Äù. Maybe if Toyota did AI‚Ä¶.. Do these OpenAI deployed engineers have the business sense, to replace the usual business process redesign ‚Äúhelp‚Äù Do these OpenAI deployed engineers have the business sense, to replace the usual business process redesign ‚Äúhelp‚Äù They don‚Äôt work solo, they are always paired with an ‚Äúecho‚Äù team member (sometimes called a deployment strategist) who is the business/pm/person who interfaces directly with the customer technical and business leads. The FDE takes their orders from the DS; the customer yells at/makes demands of the DS. The DS is responsible for initial technical requirements gathering and ‚Äúphoning home‚Äù to the company when business facets change (expansion, contraction, new opportunities, etc). They aren‚Äôt there to fully alter the purchasing customer‚Äôs business processes but to help the customer achieve their goals with their purchase of the AI services. So it is more of an on-site service partnership than an outside consultant. I lead the deployment strategist team at my company. The ‚Äúforwards deployed‚Äù vocabulary is very militaristic. This strategy of embedding technical staff in the client on an open-ended consulting / brain-siphoning engagement is held up as the secret of Palantir‚Äôs ‚Äúsuccess‚Äù. I wonder if the buzzword comes from them too‚Ä¶. Anyway, we‚Äôre doing exactly this with our AI Fintech, building a very niche model and, yes, hiring forward deployed engineers for its deployment. Hell‚Äôs bells, those photos of the ultra-refined pizza(s) are ridiculous. As every Italian knows, pizza is its own food group, but there are rules. (Although in the Undisclosed Region the use of ingredients and doughs has some jazz-like variations, given that pizza is an exotic import from Naples and not original to the Chocolate City.) Lobster and caviar defeat the purpose of pizza, which is as a comfort food that doesn‚Äôt have too much meat or fish on top. It is the dough that matters. Even amateurs know that measuring pulse after waking up is how one can gauge change over time, and that it gets lower as you get in shape. These results challenge a long-held belief, once repeated by US President Donald Trump, that the human body is like a battery with a limited energy supply and that exercise only depletes it. Why Do Spiders Decorate Their Webs? A New Piece of the Puzzle Nautilus ~~~~~~~~~~~ I find black widow webs to be the most fascinating, almost looks as if the 8 legged one was on an acid trip during construction of. So intricate and chaotic-but with a purpose. Then there was the time NASA fed various psychotropics to spiders and photographed the results. See: https://rarehistoricalphotos.com/nasa-spiders-drugs-experiment/ Here‚Äôs a video that introduced me to that research https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bZoZhM0E8Ow I work in this area and this is my experience. Large companies (and some not so large) are extremely paranoid about allowing the AI companies to use their vital information for training. The major AI players all sell private instances where users are assured that no one outside of their company can use their data for training or analyze the custom models. They put language in contracts and audits are conducted by 3rd parties to verify these claims. Its above my pay grade to determine what they are really doing behind the scenes, but given the way the contracts are written it would be a major scandal if they ever got caught cheating. A big worry to many is the user sending private information to the models running in public instances which do not have these guarantees. My employer blocks these sites, and we‚Äôre all told to use the private version. A second worry that is coming on strong is the use of Chinese models like DeepSeek and Qwen (even privately maintained versions using open source) . More companies are adopting policies where these are forbidden because, I assume, the Chinese cannot be trusted. One company described it as ‚Äúgeopolitical models are forbidden‚Äù. Re: Scientists just shattered a major exercise myth This is not new. back in the 70‚Äôs a friend gave me the ‚Äúusing up extra heartbeats‚Äù thing and I pointed out that: 3 mile run at 160 beats per min 160*20 = 3200 beats warm up cool down and other activity 120 beats per min 120*40 = 4800 beats resting pulse 50 for the rest of the day 23*60*50 = 69000 beats total 3200 + 4800 +69000 = 77000 beats per day him resting pulse 72*24*60 = 103689 beats per day (this assumes that during every day activity, his pulse is the same amount above resting pulse as mine) he started taking the stairs yeah this is some seriously auld news. It‚Äôs good to get it out there anyway as lots of the kids these days are all weights and no cardio. All weights and no cardio is also auld news, and no legs day too. ‚ÄòMassimo @Rainmaker1973 Students in China are encouraged to rest and nap during school.‚Äô If those kids are doing a 12 hour day, then this is a vital necessity. And after those kids have their nap, they are ready to absorb more lessons. Even dead cars could provide a home for the growing hordes of homeless. I have mixed feelings about 12 hours per day of instruction for school children. I learned the most from my own studies after I came home from school and from the time I spent at the public library and in my room attempting to write the most convincing essay I could for a homework assignment. Once I reached an age of double digits, I estimate that many, though not all days, I may have spent more than 12 hours per day studying when I add my study at home with the time spent in the classroom. I also greatly value the time I spent learning to play a musical instrument, or wandering in nature and in museums or attending the Summer Shakespeare plays and orchestral concerts my parents brought me and my siblings to. I believe schools and parents should foster a love for learning, endless curiosity, imagination, and questioning the ‚Äòright answer‚Äô in a way I did not see or sense in the schooling of my own children. Prosecutor‚Äôs Office in Crisis (NY Times via archive.ph) America is a banana republic Under the vaulted arches of the National Union Building, a group of federal prosecutors gathered recently for what has become an all-too-common ritual: saying goodbye to colleagues. The speeches that night reflected the despondent mood inside the U.S. attorney‚Äôs office in Washington, as the lawyers who were quitting urged those staying behind to forge ahead in uncertain times. Do what‚Äôs right, they said. Speak truth to power. Uphold the rule of law. But as the hour grew later ‚Äî and the bar tab bigger ‚Äî the politics that have buffeted the office for months suddenly intruded on the evening, people who were there recounted later. In a quiet corner, away from the charcuterie and veggie dip, Jonathan Hornok, a top aide to Jeanine Pirro, the Trump appointee picked to run the office, was firing Jon Hooks, a senior prosecutor who had worked there for nearly 20 years. That a respected supervisor with a long career could be stripped of his job in the middle of a farewell party for his colleagues captured something of the Darwinian tumult that has wracked the prosecutors‚Äô office since President Trump returned to the White House and set about remaking the Justice Department in his image. It seems to me like the fascination with learning how other persons met with a miserable end is a phenomenom driven by news outlets (traditional and novel) hyping up particularly unique cases as a relatively easy sell for views/clicks etc.. The difference in the treatment is just stark.
